review_blob: Cloudy brown and orange with head diminishing to a flat ring.  Low carbonation, dull malt profile.  Aroma reminiscent of unfermented wort.  Faint floral hops.  This tastes like an NA ale to me, and truth be told, Id have given it better marks for originality if it was NA.
Assertive bitterness without too much pine or citrus gettin in the way.  I enjoyed this one and kinda with there were more of these diminutive malt IPAs in BC.
Candy sweetish with coriander up front.  Too much fruit flavour going on-and thats without the orange wedge.  For the style though...not so bad.
Oh hell yeah this was an excellent porter.  Quixotically sweet but dry, fun all around.  I wish more porters had coffee right up front like this one did.
Serviceable lager.  Only qualm I had was that it couldve had a more interesting finish, like maybe a more unique grassy hop or something.
Mild malt and hops but not boring either.  A good beer with food but nothing too exciting.  Par for the style I guess.
Excellent hop aroma and bitterness throughout.  Malt profile held up fine.  Im thinking that this would be an IPA if it were brewed in BC.
Pleasant graininess but couldve used a more interesting yeast.  Perfectly quaffable though.
Black as night with burnt brown head.  Flavour raisiny yet dry.  Supersmooth.
Gingery, orangey aroma, quite inviting.  Somewhat biscuity with restrained phenols, this was the best beer Ive tasted from Rickards.
Yow, this one had some tang and a pleasing astringent finish where so many others woulda been sweet to the core...no pun intended.   Very drinkable.
beer_name: Big Rock Rock Creek Premium Dry Cider

review_blob: Pleasurable citrus nose and smooth on the tongue though not overcomplex.  Perhaps I should have drank it at a warmer temperature; the main thing that shone through was orange peel, coriander and Unibroues usual, albeit restrained, yeast.

Orange peel, pine needles, crushed pot pourri, a solid malt base.   I was just about to wonder how a beer made in whistler could taste like something other than starbucks, suvs, and filthy lucre when I realized-oh, its made in Kamloops.  Seriously, though, this was a good ale.  And Whistler is a very pleasant place year round.
Sudsy white head, a lot of caramel in the flavour.  Pretty sweet, but it settled in and by the end of the glass was alright.  Faint yeast breadinesss.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Pours a viscous brown with languid yeast chunks.  Aromas of coffee, caramel, citric yeastiness.  At first the mouthfeel is very thick but really this is a pretty drinkable beer.
Lemony with chamomille and a bit more carbonation than I prefer.  This did not strike me as much to write home about.
Cloudy yellow the colour of straw.  Caramel aroma, noticeable in flavour along with some dry cereal notes.  Pretty thin...maybe not fresh enough.
Aroma of vinegar and strong yeast.  Initial flavour was quite vinous but settled into a sappy cola feel.  Raspberries, chocolate in the finish.  Enjoyable.

Poured a translucent yellow.  Flavours of honey and wheaty breadiness came through as did a slightly bitter finish.  This was a fine lager in my books, could knock around Molson anyday, thats for sure.
Poured clear gold with a massive billowing white head with a variety of bubble sizes.  Grainy, sweet, aroma.  Flavours of lemon, melon, strong yeast, asome heat, sweet honey in the finish.

Poured a coppery gold.  Initial flavour was bright and clean with caramel, orange peel, licorice/anise, coriander, and a hint of candy sugar.  When yeast poured in the profile became more bitter and turbid on the taste buds.
Initial skunk, oversweet profile, standard Eurohops, should have paired this with food.    Not memorable at all and hard to finish as well.

Black with hints of sugar brown around the edge; head diminishing rapidly and then gone.  Initial flavour reminiscent of snow in the mouth, a bit of coffee comes through but no sign of a lingering finish.  Perfectly drinkable but not as much flavour as I was anticipating...might be a gateway beer for someone afraid of dark beers.

Bronze colour, woody aromas and sweet.  Heavy on the tongue with smoke, yeast and a rather flat finish.  I would have enjoye this more if it had been brewed with an English yeast; the standard Unibroue one detracts from the direction the malt tries to take.
Hefty does of chocolate malt, restrained hops, a sweet finish almost akin to a mocha drink of some sort.  Cream ales are usually sweeter than I prefer, but this one wasnt so bad.

Sweet like it should be poured on pancakes, fairly assertive yeast, and a thin film of head on top that smelled just like a field of blueberries.  I like the fact that this was made with real blueberries and all, but the cloy-o-metre is off the charts with this one.
Fills the mouth with an almost oily assertiveness, and thats saying something for a lager at a hockey game!  I didnt detect any odd or nasty flavours, no metals, alloys, or fusel oddites to be found.
Pours effervescent with sticky head.  Dry, grassy, tinny, "ice-cold" flavour of a beer expecting friends to follow it down the chute.  Good with food.

Poured pitch with a brownish lacquer of a head.  Burnt stick aroma leading into a strong and somwhat one-dimensional dark malt flavour.  Charcoal, rum, plum, raisins, thing of that nature, as well as an assertive yeast flavour.

Dull white yellow with bubbly head.  Sweet yeasty aroma.  Flabour was mild with apple, lemon, belgian yeasty notes.   A bit reminiscent of a Hefe, now that I think of it, though without the phenols thank goodness.
On tap in Vernon.  A neat raspberry flavour mixed with mild graininess is what I took away from this one.  Much better than I expected it would be.
Dark and complex looking, equally interesting flavour although could do with a touch less sweetness.  Good chocolate finish, though.
Bland, simple, the only redeeming quality here was that it washed food down the gullet.  Why make a pale ale without any hops?
This is made for fans of Okanagan Springs Pale Ale and is plain in the same way.  A light brown with bitterness begging to be augmented by some dry hopping.
Smooth, malty, and not too sweet.  This is as good a session brown as Ive tasted on tap.  Id like to try this one at a warmer temperature than they serve it at, though.
beer_name: Barley Mill Nite Mare Brown Ale

review_blob: Tangy, but restrained as was the phenolic presence.  At least the food is always good at the Barley Mill.
Went down smooth without much to distinguish it from any other lager at a brewpub.  Good graininess, no adjuncty bite, so cant complain as its meant to quench.
Poured a medium brown with the usual British malt aroma.  Flavour was fairly one dimensional but nonetheless enjoyable.  Soft, generous malts, with a minor hop presence in the background.

Deep, dark brown with aroma of candy and dark fruits.  Very syrupy sweet on the tonque with some spices and cinnamon coming through.  Peaty, earthy, finish that was a welcome addition to an otherwise cloying brew.
Effervescent, fruity, yeast flavour up front and on the finish.  Not hoppy, more like a complex cider.

Pours an orangey brown with many tiny bubbles diminishing into islands in my glass.  Tinny, brackish, aroma but in the mouth is a satisfying malt and yeast combination with a good smack of hops balance.  Really enjoyed the yeast and bitter finish.

Clear bottle.  Pours a somewhat flat looking copper colour; has a thick look to it.  Aroma of coffee, diacetyl, skunk and caramellized sugar.  Strong caramel flavour with molasses, skunk and earthy hops.  Maybe this is better closer to its point of origin.

Pours a loamy red.  Herbal mint aroma.  Many tiny white bubbles around rim of glass.  Sweet brown malt flavour with just a hint of alcohol.  A bare hint, really, quite impressive for eight percent.  It is pretty sweet though.
Pours gold with a mahogany tinge.  Slight adjunct aroma with an initial sourdough bread yeasty character.  Buttery mouthfeel, spicy hops, herbal flavours swirling cataclysmically.
Pours red pink.  Medicinal aroma, reminiscent of cough syrup.  In the mouth its sweet brown malt, caramel, raspberry and coconut.  Interesting juxtaposition.
Lemony, fruity aroma.  Flavour complex and balanced ranging from overripe apricots and a wide swathe of malt notes to a heartily bitter finish.
beer_name: Black Sheep Monty Pythons Holy Grail (Bottle)

review_blob: Bronzey-red with white lace highlights.  Smooth and malty flavour with a touch of hops.  With food, this one went ineluctably down the gullet no questions asked.
Pours a medium blonde with diminishing head. Full-bodied malt with somewhat biting hops; a bit sweet on the finish but all around very drinkable.
Opaque with cherry highlights.  Intense chocolate and roast malt flavours backed by straight-ahead bitterness.  Oily.
The coriander was right there alright. I thought that this couldve done with being unfiltered and with a little less honey.   The yeast seemed begging to take centre stage.
